Introduction

Leukemia is a type of cancer affecting the blood that develops due to uncontrolled production of malignant white blood cells in the bone marrow. Various types of blood cells are formed from stem cells in the bone marrow:

  • Red blood cells (erythrocytes), responsible for oxygen transport;
  • White blood cells (leukocytes), necessary for defense against pathogens;
  • Platelet cells (thrombocytes), important for blood clotting (coagulation)

The rampant proliferation of malignant cells in the bone marrow can suppress the production of mature blood cells in the bone marrow. This causes a shortage of healthy mature blood cells. The deficiency of mature blood cells leads to symptoms.
